literallayout.computeroutput: 1 // Copyright 2018 Pascal Kraft 2 #ifndef CODE_CORE_PRECONDITIONERSWEEPING_H_ 3 #define CODE_CORE_PRECONDITIONERSWEEPING_H_ 4 5 #include 6 #include 7 #include 8 #include 9 #include 10 #include 11 #include "Waveguide.h" 12 13 extern dealii::SolverControl s; 14 extern dealii::SparseDirectUMFPACK * solver; 15 16 extern dealii::SparsityPattern sparsity_pattern, off_diag_block_lower, off_diag_block_upper; 17 18 // dealii::TrilinosWrappers::SolverDirect * solver; 19 20 21 /** 22 * \class PreconditionerSweeping 23 * \brief This class implements the DealII preconditioner interface and offers a sweeping preconditioning mechanism. 24 * 25 * Details can be found in the paper A sweeping preconditioner for time-harmonic Maxwellâ€™s equations with finite elements. The general idea is as follows: 26 * Let \f$\Omega\f$ be the computational domain (internally) truncated by an absorbing boundary condition. This domain can be split into layers along a direction (in our case \f$ z \f$ and triangulated. We therefore have a triangulation spread across multiple processes. We chose the splitting such, that the degrees of freedom are ordered process-wise. Let \f$ K \f$ be the number of Layers and \f$ T_i \quad \imath \in \{1,\ldots,K\} \f$ the parts of the triangulation. 27 * For a PML function 28 * \f[ 29 * \sigma_i (\xi) = \begin{cases} \theta \left(\frac{-1 +(i-1)l - \xi}{l} \right)^2 \quad &\xi \in [-1 + (i-2)l, -1 +(i-1)l] \\ 0,& \xi \in [-1 + (i-1)l, 1-l] \\ \Theta\left(\frac{\xi -1 +l}{l}\right)^2, & \xi \in [1-l,1]\end{cases} 30 * \f] 31 * we now regard the problem 32 * \f[ 33 * \nabla \times \tilde{\mu}_{r,i}^{-1}\nabla \times \boldsymbol{E} - \kappa^2\tilde{\epsilon}_{r,i}\boldsymbol{E} = 0 \quad \text{ in } \mathrm{int} (\mathrm{T}_{i-1}\cup\mathrm{T}_i 34 * \f] 35 * where 36 * 37 * Described in words: We put a PML into the neighboring block of the block we want to precondition and setup the system matrix for this smaller problem. This matrix we can then invert and name the Operator \f$H_i^{-1}\f$. We then define the operator 38 * \f[ 39 * S(\boldsymbol{v}) = P_{0,n_i}H_i^{-1} (\boldsymbol{v} , \boldsymbol{0})) 40 * \f] 41 * where \f$ P_{0,n_i} \f$ describes the extraction of the first \f$ n_i \f$ components. For the one block which has no neighbor the inverse of the block of the system matrix can be used. The inversion does not have to be performed numerically - a decomposition (performed by UMFPACK or MUMPS) is sufficient. 42 * 43 * \date 28.11.2016 44 * \author Pascal Kraft 45 **/ 46 class PreconditionerSweeping : dealii::TrilinosWrappers::PreconditionBase { 47 using dealii::TrilinosWrappers::PreconditionBase::vmult; 48 49 public: 50 /** 51 * This constructor is the only one that should be used at this time. 52 * \param in_own This is the number of degrees of freedom that the current process has to deal with (owned). 53 * \param in_others This is the number of degrees of freedom that the process below has. Every process has to deal with one other process. The other neighbor only contacts it for a multiplication with its own matrix block - in this case, no objects of unknown size are concerned. However: for the one process that does require more contact needs a vector tp be initialized. This vectors size is this int. 54 * \param bandwidth The number of dofs per line on average is required for the construction of matrices. 55 * \param locally_owned The degrees of freedom associated with the current process. Required for vector and matrix construction. 56 */ 57 PreconditionerSweeping(MPI_Comm in_mpi_comm, int in_own, int in_others, int in_above, int bandwidth, dealii::IndexSet locally_owned, dealii::IndexSet * in_fixed_dofs, int rank); 58 59 ~PreconditionerSweeping(); 60 61 /** 62 * For the application of the preconditioner we require the application of the inverse of \f$H\f$.
